terms.definition_text_excerpt: A legal and administrative domain that issues and governs identity items and their verification rules.
An issuance delegate that a governance area has legally authorized to issue PID-bound identity evidence under governance policy.
A network-mediated identity service used for PID issuance or delegation workflows (for example SIM-based or bank-mediated issuance), distinct from direct physical identity-item issuance.
A physical identity document or token issued under a governance area and recognized by that area for identity purposes.
Private-key material whose generation, storage, and signing operations are enforced by secure hardware boundaries.

A network endpoint exposing discovery and/or status information needed to validate document legitimacy within a governance area. In this profile, those endpoints are exposed under /.well-known/gidas/ .
Data concept used as defined by Infra [INFRA] .
Data concept used as defined by Infra [INFRA] .
Data concept used as defined by Infra [INFRA] .
Data concept used as defined by Infra [INFRA] .
Canonical serialized tuple string. In this specification, tuple expressions use : as the component delimiter, without leading/trailing whitespace around components.
A governance-recognized endpoint that publishes normative machine-readable PID requirements for a jurisdiction, including the required MRZ-derived fields and field-level validation patterns.

A list of PID requirement entries for a governance area, serialized as a JSON array [RFC8259] . Membership semantics are a set keyed by fieldId (that is, fieldId values are unique). Each entry identifies a physical identity item field (as e
Machine Readable Zone data defined in ICAO Doc 9303 [ICAO-9303] [ICAO-9303-P3] .
A set of data that identifies a person under applicable law or standards contexts.

Deterministic subject-binding value derived from canonicalized PID fields extracted from MRZ-compatible document data. Profiles MAY realize this value as a hash, commitment, or hidden proof input, provided verifier outcomes are deterministi
A verifiable credential binding a PID binding value (or equivalent hidden proof input) to a subject DID, issuer evidence, and governance verification material.
Subject DID in a GDIS binding credential , controlled by a GQSCD-class controller.
DID controller profile requiring protected key custody and signer-intent controls as defined by GQSCD Core [GQSCD-CORE] .

Open-participation publication layer used to replicate GDIS verification material across many origins. Transport and host participation semantics are defined by the declared host profile (for example GQTS), not by this specification.
External specification that defines host role semantics, admission, transport, replication, and consistency behavior for publication participants (for example GQTS). [GQTS-CORE] .
Governance-required publication targets in the selected host profile that define a minimum publication floor and not an exclusive publication ceiling.
Union of mandatory governance publication targets and person-selected additional targets to which subject materials are published.
URI query parameter whose value is an RFC 3339 date-time selecting the policy version that was effective at that instant [RFC3339] .

Governance-declared method profile describing how physical identity item authenticity and validity are checked (for example MRZ-only or MRZ plus NFC chip checks), including deterministic verifier acceptance/failure rules.
Machine-readable reference to an authoritative governance source used in physical-validity or recognition checks (for example a trusted list, registry, or official legal publication endpoint).
An evidence artifact proving which physical validity method profile was applied, which evidence checks were executed, and which governance trust source reference values were used.
A signed or hashed machine-verifiable artifact used by issuers, host-profile operators, or verifiers to substantiate a security or status claim.
Implementation report that states conformance class coverage, policy assumptions, test outputs, and produced or consumed evidence artifact types.
Deterministic output object produced by a verifier after executing the normative processing rules in this specification.

requirement_maps.description: Low-cost divergence detection via compact head metadata.

terms.definition_text_excerpt: A phone, tablet, laptop, desktop, or hardware authenticator operated by a natural person in signature workflows.
Data uniquely used by the signatory to create an electronic signature; aligned with eIDAS terminology for electronic signature creation data ( [EU-910/2014] ).
Cryptographic private key material used as [=signature creation data=] in digital signature mechanisms ( [RFC7515] , [RFC9052] ).

A [=signature creation key=] whose generation, storage, and cryptographic use are enforced by protected hardware boundaries with non-exportability controls ( [ANDROID-KEYSTORE] , [MSFT-TPM] , [APPLE-SE] ).
Device class defined by eIDAS and evaluated against Annex II outcomes and referenced assessment standards ( [EU-910/2014] , [EU-2016/650] ).
Security objective that signature creation data can be used only under control of the legitimate signatory, as required by Annex II outcome language ( [EU-910/2014] ).

Complete interaction in which the signer can inspect what is being signed and explicitly authorize the operation, with security-critical portions mediated by trusted platform paths when available ( [ANDROID-PROTECTED-CONFIRMATION] , [WEBAUT

The exact full payload byte sequence presented to and approved by the signer before signature creation; this profile does not permit signing operations where only a partial or transformed subset is shown as the approval target ( [EU-ANNEX-I
JSON object attached to an artifact that carries cryptographic proof metadata and proof bytes so a verifier can check integrity and authenticity deterministically ( [VC-DI] ).

[=proof object=] type defined by the W3C Data Integrity model; in this profile it is used for profile-level integrity claims and is paired with the selected cryptosuite and proofValue members ( [VC-DI] , [VC-DI-ECDSA] ).

Verification model where each decision is based on explicit per-transaction evidence and policy evaluation, rather than implicit trust in network location, client software, or governance labels alone ( [NIST-SP-800-207] , [RFC7515] , [RFC90
Set of hardware, firmware, and software components that must behave correctly to uphold stated security properties ( [ETSI-319401] ).
Machine-verifiable artifact set used to substantiate technical or legal property claims ( [ETSI-319401] , [EU-2016/650] ).

Deployment-defined HTTPS discovery location used to publish evidence metadata and pointers for decentralized verifier retrieval in this profile ( [RFC8615] , [RFC9110] , [GDIS-CORE] , REQ-GDIS-05 , getSchemeDescriptor , getEndpointKindCatal
Model where signature creation data remains on the signatory-operated [=end-user device=] and is not duplicated to remote service custody.
Model where signature creation data is created, managed, or activated in server-side trust-service components external to the signatory device ( [CEN-419241-1] , [ETSI-119431-1] , [ETSI-119431-2] ).
Primary interoperability profile in this specification, based on globally deployed web and internet standards ( [WEBCRYPTO-L2] , [WEBAUTHN-L3] , [RFC7515] , [RFC9052] ).
Mapping layer from [=web profile=] artifacts to EU legal and ecosystem evidence requirements ( [EU-910/2014] , [EU-2016/650] , [EU-2024/2979] , [EU-2024/2982] ).

Claim that an actor, service, device, or signature has legal qualified status within a defined jurisdiction; such claims require authoritative status evidence ( [EU-TRUSTED-LISTS] , [EU-QSCD-NOTIFICATIONS] ).
EU legal framework for electronic identification and trust services established by Regulation (EU) No 910/2014 and its amendments ( [EU-910/2014] , [EU-2024/1183] ).

{ certificate of conformity, certification report, certification report URL, certified configuration identifiers (hardware/firmware/software versions), validity dates and status, certification body identity }
An HTTP origin that serves GQTS resources and MAY ingest, replicate, and gossip append-only signed-token history material.
A machine-readable object describing one trust-service instance, its type, and its current token-chain head state.
A machine-readable governance-scoped object describing naming rules, proof profile, canonicalization profile, and publication floor requirements.
Publicly retrievable trust data used by verifiers, including verification methods, controller references, status metadata, and signed event history. Wallet-private claims are out of scope.
A scoped signed-token stream identified by a log identifier where entries form an append-only directed linear history.
Identifier of the latest accepted token for an event namespace , used for cheap synchronization checks before heavy retrieval.
A signed token that reconciles competing candidate heads while preserving one canonical previous-token pointer in the accepted chain.

A candidate event entry that fails deterministic acceptance checks (for example schema, previous-token linkage, key-lineage constraints, or proof verification) and is therefore rejected from accepted history.
A verifier result stating that schema constraints, signatures/proofs, canonicalization, and signed-token chain requirements were satisfied.
A policy output derived from external governance sources (for example trusted lists, legal registries, contractual trust anchors), separate from mechanical validity .
A normalized identifier for governance-scoped objects. In this profile, values MUST be lowercase ASCII and match the pattern defined by the OpenAPI schema `GovernanceCode` .

requirement_maps.description: Service descriptor active token-chain state publication.
Low-cost head-token synchronization and merge-reconciliation metadata publication.
